Doug, 

Those senior members of the group are my friends.

If you've read what I wrote as blaming the group, you got it completely
wrong, and that would be an inappropriate conclusion on your own part.

Please don't turn this into a pissy flame war because honestly this is
not a good situation and I'm just asking people to be on the lookout. 

For what I'm saying, it's just that as information percolates and
disseminates from meeting attendees to friends, to possibly sketchy
friends, it is not clear what the long term effects are so that those of
us who are used to sword value being completely under the radar have to
start being a bit more alert.

Six degrees of separation are between every person in North America.

This means that chances are extremely good that some friend of a friend
of a friend is a thief.

This is what I'm indicating.

- darcy

<dblain@...> writes:

> As a member of this new study group, I take exception to your
> statement that this group may be responsible in any way for an
> increase in sword related crimes. Clearly you have major issues with
> the courier you are using and the police should be involved
> immediately upon any suspicious activity, but please do not besmirch
> the efforts of the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre as it attempts to
> educate people on the samurai sword. Senior members of the JSS/US are
> active participants in this group and I am sure they are not going to
> be a party to any activity that does not promote a complete respect
> for the sword and its history. Sorry to vent, but this was not an
> appropriate conclusion on your part.
> ____________________________________________ Doug Blain, Manager,
> Information Technology Security Computing & Communications Services,
> University of Guelph Phone: (519) 824-4120 ext. 56475 Fax: (519)
> 767-1620

>   ----- Original Message ----- 
>   From: samurai@... 
>   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
>   Sent: Friday, January 21, 2005 11:12 AM
>   Subject: [nihontostudy] stolen sword alert



>   A Tokubetsu Juyo Yukimitsu was stolen in transit from me to Japan. 

>   Last year a Juyo Token Niji Kunitoshi was taken in the same manner, it
>   was scanned by someone as being sent to Canada Customs, then it
>   vanished. There was a several week period in both cases of me having to
>   fight people who's computer screens told them something that wasn't
>   true, then finally they admitted the package vanished into thin air.

>   Last year they searched the warehouse several times without it turning
>   up, and when I said I was sending the police over, 15 minutes later the
>   sword appeared in some office where someone had "mistakenly left it"
>   after scanning that it was sent to customs.

>   My hope is that the same scam is being played again.

>   Obviously with the cost of a blade like this, it is not a trivial matter
>   and I feel kind of sick. Insurance says they will not cover it. 

>   Pictures of the blade are on my site as I have the paperwork.

>   It has gone missing or been stolen in the Toronto area. Lately there
>   has been a new study group formed in Toronto with a lot of attendees. It
>   is possible with the new dissemination of information there that there
>   is more knowledge about the value of these swords and so we're going to
>   start seeing more thefts. 

>   Here's the link to my site:

>   http://www.nihonto.ca/yukimitsu-2/

>   Please, everyone be on the lookout for someone who is asking questions
>   about an antique sword that they have found, and are trying to get the
>   value of that matches the pictures and description on my site. If
>   someone presents it to you in person, please take it and call the police
>   immediately.

>   - darcy
